Play," which looks like the groaninss Of dsap-
pointed politician. When man, in an aHray.
gets knocked down. he is very likely to cry out
Fair Play" Fair Play"-although he may have
been the aggressor in the onset. 8. Fair PIayv
speaks OF several violent articles in your paper.
but has not pointed them out. i" Fair Play" wish
es to screen Mr.. Hatker from the charge of incon-
sistency (o which he surely is guilty by charging
it on you. /" Fair play'' says you ought to pub
lish the article, wherein Mr.. Harker dcnounces
General Jackson as the g most Objectionable of all
the Presidential Candidates.. would ask " Fair
Play" whether MIR. Harker would not republish


it himself, il he not guilty of the charge in the
fullest extent :. Fair Play" says we sup
port man for office for the first time, are we
bound to support him during his life, be his con-
duct what it will 20 In answer, / would ask
:" Fair Play" whether, if he had denounced per-
son as entirely unfit for office five years ago.
and the same objections were still in force, could
he support him now cit consistency ?-or if his
opinions had undergone change, would he have
any objection to explain the why, aad wherefore.
never heard that you had any hand in opening
the book that " Fair Play speaks of, or whether
you did or did not sign for Jackson at that time.
II you did. your subsequent conduct only proves
you to be the dsinterested, honest man. willing to
approve of the wise !. actings and dongs'' Of the

to sacrifice American manufactures, Internal I'M
provement, and in short the best interests of your
country, for the purpose Of electing General jack
son twho Mr.. Harker says is such dangerous
man,) our next President. The latter part Of the

this county, as he says you had several {" names

never understood you were the cause of all this
but even if you we're, the largest number of the

these local matters that only concern those who

Newcastle and its vicinity disposed to unite in forming
Military Volunteer Corps. according to previous notices
held st the House of George Gould. in Newcastle,
Saturday the 24h inst, c. D. Blaney. Esq appointed
Charman-who stated the object of the meeting; after
which the following resolutions were adopted:


Res0Ued That we approve Of the objects Of this meet


five be appointed procure the of such persons
may be disposed to unite in promoting the formation os
Volunteer Corps.-The following persons appoin-
ted ;-Wm Msgens. S. Nj. Couper, VIM D. MccFone,
James Smith, jun. and Sam'l. Barr, jun.


Resolvea, That this meeting adjourn to Thursday nexts
the officers of the Company shall be elected provided
sufficient number Of persons shall then be enrolled to form
Company-and that the proceedings of this meeting be
published in the Watchman the Delaware Gazette, and
in hand bills. G. ID. BLANEY, Chairman.


March 3D. 1897.
AT a meeting of the citizens Of

though when It was opened, he "did there record his
name for General Jackson" Did FAIR Play sup
pose that by publishing this circumstance, which
was already we'll known, he could relieve his
friend Mr.. Harker from the unpleasant situation
in which he has been placed by ssight Of what
he had said on former occasion''p If so. he has
been most egregiously in error. There is vast
difference between preferring one man, and after
wards supporting his more successful competitor
who has been constitutionally and fairly elected
and vlllifying man in the most disgraceful man.
ner, and then turning round and supporting him
although there has been no change in the disposi-
tion or character of the person SO abused.


We are not ashamed to say that we still hold
General Jackson in very high estimation, and our
the fact that there has never appeared any thing
disrespectful or abusive of him in the columns Of
the Watchman. Nor shall there be whilst we have
any control over them.


As to what " Fair Play" says of our conduct in
relation to the Democratic party, it is scarcely
worth notice. To the interest of that party we
have been devoted--for its good we have made ma
ny sacrfces-and the Watchman has ever firmly
and independently maintained the rights of the
majority Of that party against the Vaccinations Of
the factious and intriguing. S Fair Play'' as
crbes more influence to US than we had the vanity
to suppose we possessed, and we can hardly admit
that he really believed that we had such control
ling power over the Democratic party that we could
induce them to strike of names from regularly NOM
lated tickets, and divide their party. We believe
that :" Fair Play" has better knowledge Of the


Democratic Party. He knows that they are bo-
dy Of intelligent and rejecting freemen, who duly
prize the inestmable rights purchased by the blood
Of their forefathers and who think and act for them
selves as becomes citizens Of this great republic.


And to say that we could divide or sway such men,
is an absurdity that will not obtain credit.


Mr. Harker in his Gazette of the goth inst says" The


Adams stock has experienced very rapid decline within
few weeks in this place. We could name some dozen


of persons, who within about week, have left him."


&c. Now, seriously ask Mr.. Harker few questions


Have you been guilty of making gross msrepresena


ton in the above statement? Did you in penning the


paragraph from which the above quotation is aken be-
eye it TO be true whether it was so /?


Could you your depended upon making good your


seri0n, g NAME your "some dozen of persons!"

relief of the suffering Greeks.

AT Baltimore, on Friday.

has become our painful duty to rec ord another steam
boat disaster and another sacrifice of human life. Tho
boiler of the steamboat Oliver Ellsworth which plies be
tween this city and Hartford, explodedor rather in steam
boat phraseoogy, the coapsehuc burst-on Thursday
evening, half past o'clock, miles from Saybrook
the passage to New York. Mr.. Henry G. Porter, OF
Hartford who Of the passengers has called on
and communicated tho following particulars g.


Seven Of the passengers and three OF the crew were
scaded One Of the latter, named Andruss died in few
hours, and was buried yesterday, at Saybrook.
The Rev. DR. Spring, Of this city. with Mr. Stephen
Lockwood Of the elders of his church, on board
returning from Hartford whittier they had been to attend
the installation of the brother OF Dr. over the third Con-
grega,iona church in Hartford We regret state that
Mr. L most estimable man is badly-nay, dangerously
scaded He passing the boiler at the moment OF the
explosion, and his face is badly scaded He was in the
act Of inspiration, at the moment and is feared that the
lungs injured


MIR. Penfeld the Engineer, who belongs in this city,
badly scaldedThe steward Of the boat is also among
the scalded.


Kessrs Eratus Goodwin Of Hartford Asahe Hinckley,
Of do and Stephen q. Gardiner, of Weathersfeld
all considerably acalded


U. s. Sic per Cent Stocks.-It may be of i'm
portance to such of our readers as may be either
holders of or dealers in U. S. Stocks, to know.
says the N. Y. Post, that the bill for exchanging
the 16 millions of six per cent. stock OF 1918, now
redeemable at the pleasure of Government, which
passed one house of Congress, did not become a
law. In consequence, interest, at the rate OF six
per cent, will continue to be paid to the present
holders, until the state Of the Treasury may autho
rize the payment Of large instalment of the prin
cipal. This may perhaps be the case at the end OIL
this year, at least to the amount OF several mil
lions.


The above is the bill that was recently spoken
of by our Washington correspondent. the failure of
which in the Senate, causes the loss Of very large
sum 10 the Geyernment7 Bait Pat.

The Corn Question has been again postponed, to
he o6th of February, in consideration OF Mr. Can


n;ngs illness, which was so far removed as to leave
[l;t,e doubt that on that day the Right Hon. Gen.

noned. should Mr.. Canning not be SO far recovered
as to resume his seat before the day fixed for its


Addresses Of coincidence to the King, on the oc-
cas;on of the death of the Duke of York NOV
/ ed in both houses Of Parliament, on the 18th of
February. In the Lords, the address was moved
by the Earl Of Liverpool, and in the Commons by
! Mr. Secretary Peel. They were carried unani
/ son spoke in favor.


The Catholic Association, instigated BY Mr. o.
Connel, who but short time ago was hand and


uoye' with Cobbett, have voted Cobbett's Register
out Of the Association. The immediate offence of
Cobbett was some remarks upon Counsellor Brio,
who lately fell in duel. A Mr.. O'Dwyer, and a
Mr. Barrett, also spoke with great bitterness of
Cobbett. We copy the following paragraph as a


fair specimen of what all the speakers said of their
4 late fllenu anu CnatnplOn -


.This old English ruf6an and in6del revied
your most tried and long faithful advocates-and
you permitted it. Well, it is not too late The
calumniator Of the living has been also the violator


of the dead-( hear, hear, hear, ibis tell hate had
followed its victim to the very grave he has dar-
ed to disturb to profane, with unseemly mirth and
ribalal Jest, and hideons laughter, the cold, and
lonely, and silent, and defenceless tomb.-( Loud
cheers. think see him, like vuture, hover
! ING over the young mans dying moments, and
with gross black wing brushing across his radiant
spirit as it mounts to the skies. s."-Loro continued
cheering"


1t is said that Sir Walter Scott will receive a
large pccuniary augmentation from his publishers
in consequence of the Life Of .Napoteon." ex-
tending to eight volumes. 1t is doubted whether
the work will be published in London in less than
three months from the present time.
The late William Clifford left fortune of 25, ,000
accumulated as editor of the Quarterly Review,
and as the writer Of political essays.
The death of two Generals is announced within
the second week in February, namely; Gen. W.
Cartwright, Colonel of the lst dragon guards) |;
and 1t. Gen. Ramsay, of the royal artillery.


II is said to be the intention of the British Admi-


ralty to build six steam ships of the largest size,
capable Of carrying 100 carronade guns of increas


ed cal,bre, and to be propelled by two engines Of


two hundred horse power each.


The naval estimates we're brought on in the


House Of Commons on the 18th. One new item


Of expense, which occurs in them, is that caused by


the erection of mills, to furnish a supply of flour


for the navy. The Importance Of this arrangement


will be understood from the fact, stated by Sir g.


Clerk, that adutcration of -four contracted for, had


been carried on to such an extent, that in the last


year, no fewer than sic thousand sacks had been
thrown back on the contractors hands
FROM FRANCE.-The Cadmus, from Havre,
brings us numerous files OF Paris papers to the 18th
Of February. The Constitutional and Etole are
almost exclusively occupied with the proceedings of
the Chamber of Deputies upon the proposed law OF
the press. The debates ran high.
OF news, these papers are all unusually barren.
We can CLEAN but few items, and those Of little
moment


The Constitutional says. great number OF the
electors of Paris. greatly alarmed by succession
OF ministerial acts and projects which threaten to
deprive them of the rights guaranteed to them by
the charter, are at this moment signing petition


to the King.


The Russian Ambassador had issued cards of in


ytation to the number Of 800 or 600, for grand


ball to be given on the 90 Of February. The Mar


shals of France are all addressed by their titles


and not by their names, as was the when invit-


ed by the Austrian Ambassador.


The municipal authorities of Paris have appro-
priated $4,000 francs for an extraordinary distli


button among the INDECENT of that city.

into papcs that arrangement OF the difference


on the Colonial question with Great Britain had been made
by Mr. GALLArIH, we have taken pains to inquire
into the truh of it, We learn that there is no ground
whatever for ths report but that the contrary Great


Britain perseveres in aog refusing treat that
question: There is therefore. prospect Whatever OF
1 any adjustment of it by convention


now more than ever matter of regret that Con-


gres should have adjourned without passing any new law

nttees of the Houses specified the conditions on which

Mr.. Harker having found the unpalatable truth
contained in our violent articles" respecting his
former opinion of Gen. Jackson, so cutting and
severe, that he swore off from any further notice
of them, has procured correspondent to act as
champion in his defence. This correspondent,
who signs himself 6 Fair Play" accuses US of act
ing unfairly in publishing one single paragraph"
to "prove" Mr.. Harkcr's " inconsistency" and
says that an honest editor should have published
the whole artice.'' We would plead guilty to the
charge of unfairness, had we, in selecting quo
tation from Mr.. Harker's opinion Of Gen. Jackson
in 1922, attempted to misreprcsent his sentiments
or pervert his language. But this we have not
done. We have only given his own words, express
sed after mature delbcration. We would suppose
that the remark of Fair Play respecting the duty
of an honest editor,' would come home to Mr..
IIarker, as the latter has said that an honest man
cannot be shamed by sight of what he has said
on a former OCCASION" Now, according to Mr..
Harker's own rule, he is not " fan honest man''-
for he is ashamed to repubish what he said of Gen.
Jackson in 1892 Or, if he is an honest man, he


IS co,oardty one, for he is afraid to republsh what
he then said of the General, when, in comparing him
with Messrs. Clay, Clinton, Adams, Calhoun and
Crawford, he made use Of the following language.


"Of ALL the gentlemen named Gen jackson appears
to to be the MOST OBJECTIONABLE. That he is
man of energy, no one will doubt but we think that
in chief magistrate of the United States, foe much
ergy Is extremely dangerous; AND have seen IN THE
GENERAL snch DISREGARD FOR THE INSTITU-
TIONS of the country, such DISPOSITION place
himself ABOVE IT'S iazvs, AND such an INCLINATION 10
TRAMPLE ON THE RIGHTS OF OTHERS, when
tbnvc tnod in wiz OWN INTEREST or
FEELINGS. should render the citizens of the United
States very cautious about placing him in the first Office
within their gift"


We have not given up our intention to republish
the whole article from which the above is quoted; !;
though we still think that Mr.. Iiarker is under
every obligation which could influence gentleman,
to be the first to present it to the public.


Had it been merely a question Of preference
with Mr.. Harker, in 1922, between Gen. Jackson
and any other candidate for the presidency, we
should not have charged him with inconsistency,
or deemed him worthy Of reproach, for now sup
porting man to whom he was then opposed
1t is " the reasons which Mr.. Harkcr gave for
that opposition, which lay him open to the charge
of and hypocrcy, and servlity to his
masters, and which are always brought to mind
when we see him pleading with the people to sup
port man for the high Office of President of the
United States, respecting whom he once said that
HInc ClllZHUS SUOulu Ue CgTy CuWtoUS duUut pid-
cling him in the first office within their gift"


Now the question arises, has Gen. Jackson
changed his disposition? If in 1929, before that
period. he disregarded the institutions of his coun
try If he then placed himself above its laws and
ifhe then trampled the rights of others, to pro-
mote his own interests, would he not under SINH
lar circumstances, act as he then did


But in what consisted all these odious traits of
character which Mr. Harker saw in the General,
,rd ,,,I,h Iol him IN cautinp he pp0plp auainQf
supporting him for the presidency Why, he dis
charged his duty with frmness which did HIM
honor, and which the emergencies of the times full
ly justified. He gave no quarters to traitors and
tores-and he declared that if he had been com.
mander in New England. he would have hung the
members of that infamous band of blue lights who
composed the Hartford Convention. For this de-
claration, Mr.. Harker and his correspondents
poured upon cold Hickory" such torrents of
abuse as would have disgraced the veriest black
guard in creation. After this, we ask any man if
Mr. Harker is not guilty of every charge we have
made against him Of inconsistency, &c. in now ad-
vocating the cause of Gen. Jackson ? Who will
deny that he IS led by the nose by few men who, |
in 1922, thought no better of Gen. Jackson than
Mr.. Harker himself did, and who are now found in
the ranks of his supporters only because they flat
ter themselves that their own views will be promo
ted thereby Their golden prospects vanished like
dream when Mr.. Adams was elected, and their
oppositon to him is the effects of disappointed
ambition. The result of the next presidential
election may prove that they again wrong in
their calculations.


For the information of "Fair Play'' and the
public we would state that Albert Wilson, so tar
from being one of the most active individuals in
wilmington, in causing Book to be opened at
the Lafayette Iiotcl,' during the last Presidential
election, had nothing to do with procuring the Books

have thrown together few thoughts the subject o
EDucAroN, which have made Of in its broades
Education, by It's plastic and benign influence. produces
on the recipient creation; and enables the individual
upon whom it is advantageously employed, to deveope
his moral and physical eneges and thus to become
shining example his fellows, and active and useful
member of Society. Education, when it works properly
noble mind, ects to view those latent virtues and
energies, which, in the absence of it, would forever
main buried and lost both to the individual and to Society
Education is very apty and justly compared the culture
of the sell for, if DO not plough and SOW shall have
CROP BY the inyarabe laws of nature, it the spring
put forth blossoms in there will be beauty,
and in autumn fruit So, youth be aed away with
out improvement, manhood will be contemplate and old
age miserable and then vice will take possession of the
heart and bring forth uxurant crop Of the most baleful
propenstes and passions Education and virtue gene
rally coeva spring up spontaneously together and while
the enghcns, the other orti6es the heart Educa
ton is the fountain Of all those moral and social virtues
which alone adorn human nature, and render the
model of perfection 1t is education which swee
tens the temper and renders the recipient amabe and
aabe 1t expands the intellect, eevates the affections
and raises above all sublunay scenery; and we are
enabled to travel far the solar walk, or the milky
way, and, now and then, to sit among the stars.

the factious and intriguing. S Fair Play'' as
crbes more influence to US than we had the vanity
to suppose we possessed, and we can hardly admit
that he really believed that we had such control
ling power over the Democratic party that we could
induce them to strike of names from regularly NOM
lated tickets, and divide their party. We believe
that :" Fair Play" has better knowledge Of the


Democratic Party. He knows that they are bo-
dy Of intelligent and rejecting freemen, who duly
prize the inestmable rights purchased by the blood
Of their forefathers and who think and act for them
selves as becomes citizens Of this great republic.


And to say that we could divide or sway such men,
is an absurdity that will not obtain credit.


Mr. Harker in his Gazette of the goth inst says" The


Adams stock has experienced very rapid decline within
few weeks in this place. We could name some dozen


of persons, who within about week, have left him."


&c. Now, seriously ask Mr.. Harker few questions


Have you been guilty of making gross msrepresena


ton in the above statement? Did you in penning the


paragraph from which the above quotation is aken be-
eye it TO be true whether it was so /?


Could you your depended upon making good your


seri0n, g NAME your "some dozen of persons!"


| 1t is mentioned as very singular coincidence
that Doctor, alias Gen. Floyd, of combination


memory, and the famous race horse Eclipse, re-
Gently arrived in Richmond at the same time.
| PHILADELPHIA, March 24-The brig Tontine, Captain


HARRs sailed yesterday morning from this port for Gambia,


with twenyhree hundred barrels of provisions for the


relief of the suffering Greeks.


Miss Liyermore is preaching in Philadelphia.

has become our painful duty to rec ord another steam
boat disaster and another sacrifice of human life. Tho
boiler of the steamboat Oliver Ellsworth which plies be
tween this city and Hartford, explodedor rather in steam
boat phraseoogy, the coapsehuc burst-on Thursday
evening, half past o'clock, miles from Saybrook
the passage to New York. Mr.. Henry G. Porter, OF
Hartford who Of the passengers has called on
and communicated tho following particulars g.


Seven Of the passengers and three OF the crew were
scaded One Of the latter, named Andruss died in few
hours, and was buried yesterday, at Saybrook.
The Rev. DR. Spring, Of this city. with Mr. Stephen
Lockwood Of the elders of his church, on board
returning from Hartford whittier they had been to attend
the installation of the brother OF Dr. over the third Con-
grega,iona church in Hartford We regret state that
Mr. L most estimable man is badly-nay, dangerously
scaded He passing the boiler at the moment OF the
explosion, and his face is badly scaded He was in the
act Of inspiration, at the moment and is feared that the
lungs injured


MIR. Penfeld the Engineer, who belongs in this city,
badly scaldedThe steward Of the boat is also among
the scalded.


Kessrs Eratus Goodwin Of Hartford Asahe Hinckley,
Of do and Stephen q. Gardiner, of Weathersfeld
all considerably acalded


U. s. Sic per Cent Stocks.-It may be of i'm
portance to such of our readers as may be either
holders of or dealers in U. S. Stocks, to know.
says the N. Y. Post, that the bill for exchanging
the 16 millions of six per cent. stock OF 1918, now
redeemable at the pleasure of Government, which
passed one house of Congress, did not become a
law. In consequence, interest, at the rate OF six
per cent, will continue to be paid to the present
holders, until the state Of the Treasury may autho
rize the payment Of large instalment of the prin
cipal. This may perhaps be the case at the end OIL
this year, at least to the amount OF several mil
lions.


The above is the bill that was recently spoken
of by our Washington correspondent. the failure of
which in the Senate, causes the loss Of very large
sum 10 the Geyernment7 Bait Pat.

full articles.article:
to the 5th Of February. Shipping List of the
|fah. and Liverpool papers to the 10th all inclu-
sye. and by the packet ship Cadmus, Capt. Al
In, from Hayre, numerous files of Paris papers
IN to the 10th Of February, inclusive.
The Corn Question has been again postponed, to
he o6th of February, in consideration OF Mr. Can


n;ngs illness, which was so far removed as to leave
[l;t,e doubt that on that day the Right Hon. Gen.
f.eman would be able to bring the question forward


n is confidently anticipated that Sir F. Burdet's
motion respecting the Catholics will be also post


noned. should Mr.. Canning not be SO far recovered
as to resume his seat before the day fixed for its


Addresses Of coincidence to the King, on the oc-
cas;on of the death of the Duke of York NOV
/ ed in both houses Of Parliament, on the 18th of
February. In the Lords, the address was moved
by the Earl Of Liverpool, and in the Commons by
! Mr. Secretary Peel. They were carried unani
/ son spoke in favor.


The Catholic Association, instigated BY Mr. o.
Connel, who but short time ago was hand and


uoye' with Cobbett, have voted Cobbett's Register
out Of the Association. The immediate offence of
Cobbett was some remarks upon Counsellor Brio,
who lately fell in duel. A Mr.. O'Dwyer, and a
Mr. Barrett, also spoke with great bitterness of
Cobbett. We copy the following paragraph as a


fair specimen of what all the speakers said of their
4 late fllenu anu CnatnplOn -


.This old English ruf6an and in6del revied
your most tried and long faithful advocates-and
you permitted it. Well, it is not too late The
calumniator Of the living has been also the violator


of the dead-( hear, hear, hear, ibis tell hate had
followed its victim to the very grave he has dar-
ed to disturb to profane, with unseemly mirth and
ribalal Jest, and hideons laughter, the cold, and
lonely, and silent, and defenceless tomb.-( Loud
cheers. think see him, like vuture, hover
! ING over the young mans dying moments, and
with gross black wing brushing across his radiant
spirit as it mounts to the skies. s."-Loro continued
cheering"


1t is said that Sir Walter Scott will receive a
large pccuniary augmentation from his publishers
in consequence of the Life Of .Napoteon." ex-
tending to eight volumes. 1t is doubted whether
the work will be published in London in less than
three months from the present time.
The late William Clifford left fortune of 25, ,000
accumulated as editor of the Quarterly Review,
and as the writer Of political essays.
The death of two Generals is announced within
the second week in February, namely; Gen. W.
Cartwright, Colonel of the lst dragon guards) |;
and 1t. Gen. Ramsay, of the royal artillery.


II is said to be the intention of the British Admi-


ralty to build six steam ships of the largest size,
capable Of carrying 100 carronade guns of increas


ed cal,bre, and to be propelled by two engines Of


two hundred horse power each.


The naval estimates we're brought on in the


House Of Commons on the 18th. One new item


Of expense, which occurs in them, is that caused by


the erection of mills, to furnish a supply of flour


for the navy. The Importance Of this arrangement


will be understood from the fact, stated by Sir g.


Clerk, that adutcration of -four contracted for, had


been carried on to such an extent, that in the last


year, no fewer than sic thousand sacks had been
thrown back on the contractors hands
FROM FRANCE.-The Cadmus, from Havre,
brings us numerous files OF Paris papers to the 18th
Of February. The Constitutional and Etole are
almost exclusively occupied with the proceedings of
the Chamber of Deputies upon the proposed law OF
the press. The debates ran high.
OF news, these papers are all unusually barren.
We can CLEAN but few items, and those Of little
moment


The Constitutional says. great number OF the
electors of Paris. greatly alarmed by succession
OF ministerial acts and projects which threaten to
deprive them of the rights guaranteed to them by
the charter, are at this moment signing petition


to the King.


The Russian Ambassador had issued cards of in


ytation to the number Of 800 or 600, for grand


ball to be given on the 90 Of February. The Mar


shals of France are all addressed by their titles


and not by their names, as was the when invit-


ed by the Austrian Ambassador.


The municipal authorities of Paris have appro-
priated $4,000 francs for an extraordinary distli


button among the INDECENT of that city.
- cCpfpnS C-


Washington lfarch 26 "A report having found lis way


into papcs that arrangement OF the difference


on the Colonial question with Great Britain had been made
by Mr. GALLArIH, we have taken pains to inquire
into the truh of it, We learn that there is no ground
whatever for ths report but that the contrary Great


Britain perseveres in aog refusing treat that
question: There is therefore. prospect Whatever OF
1 any adjustment of it by convention


now more than ever matter of regret that Con-


gres should have adjourned without passing any new law
The bill which simultaneously reported by the Com


nttees of the Houses specified the conditions on which
| ths Government wiling to place the trade. They

Mr.. Harker having found the unpalatable truth
contained in our violent articles" respecting his
former opinion of Gen. Jackson, so cutting and
severe, that he swore off from any further notice
of them, has procured correspondent to act as
champion in his defence. This correspondent,
who signs himself 6 Fair Play" accuses US of act
ing unfairly in publishing one single paragraph"
to "prove" Mr.. Harkcr's " inconsistency" and
says that an honest editor should have published
the whole artice.'' We would plead guilty to the
charge of unfairness, had we, in selecting quo
tation from Mr.. Harker's opinion Of Gen. Jackson
in 1922, attempted to misreprcsent his sentiments
or pervert his language. But this we have not
done. We have only given his own words, express
sed after mature delbcration. We would suppose
that the remark of Fair Play respecting the duty
of an honest editor,' would come home to Mr..
IIarker, as the latter has said that an honest man
cannot be shamed by sight of what he has said
on a former OCCASION" Now, according to Mr..
Harker's own rule, he is not " fan honest man''-
for he is ashamed to repubish what he said of Gen.
Jackson in 1892 Or, if he is an honest man, he


IS co,oardty one, for he is afraid to republsh what
he then said of the General, when, in comparing him
with Messrs. Clay, Clinton, Adams, Calhoun and
Crawford, he made use Of the following language.


"Of ALL the gentlemen named Gen jackson appears
to to be the MOST OBJECTIONABLE. That he is
man of energy, no one will doubt but we think that
in chief magistrate of the United States, foe much
ergy Is extremely dangerous; AND have seen IN THE
GENERAL snch DISREGARD FOR THE INSTITU-
TIONS of the country, such DISPOSITION place
himself ABOVE IT'S iazvs, AND such an INCLINATION 10
TRAMPLE ON THE RIGHTS OF OTHERS, when
tbnvc tnod in wiz OWN INTEREST or
FEELINGS. should render the citizens of the United
States very cautious about placing him in the first Office
within their gift"


We have not given up our intention to republish
the whole article from which the above is quoted; !;
though we still think that Mr.. Iiarker is under
every obligation which could influence gentleman,
to be the first to present it to the public.


Had it been merely a question Of preference
with Mr.. Harker, in 1922, between Gen. Jackson
and any other candidate for the presidency, we
should not have charged him with inconsistency,
or deemed him worthy Of reproach, for now sup
porting man to whom he was then opposed
1t is " the reasons which Mr.. Harkcr gave for
that opposition, which lay him open to the charge
of and hypocrcy, and servlity to his
masters, and which are always brought to mind
when we see him pleading with the people to sup
port man for the high Office of President of the
United States, respecting whom he once said that
HInc ClllZHUS SUOulu Ue CgTy CuWtoUS duUut pid-
cling him in the first office within their gift"


Now the question arises, has Gen. Jackson
changed his disposition? If in 1929, before that
period. he disregarded the institutions of his coun
try If he then placed himself above its laws and
ifhe then trampled the rights of others, to pro-
mote his own interests, would he not under SINH
lar circumstances, act as he then did


But in what consisted all these odious traits of
character which Mr. Harker saw in the General,
,rd ,,,I,h Iol him IN cautinp he pp0plp auainQf
supporting him for the presidency Why, he dis
charged his duty with frmness which did HIM
honor, and which the emergencies of the times full
ly justified. He gave no quarters to traitors and
tores-and he declared that if he had been com.
mander in New England. he would have hung the
members of that infamous band of blue lights who
composed the Hartford Convention. For this de-
claration, Mr.. Harker and his correspondents
poured upon cold Hickory" such torrents of
abuse as would have disgraced the veriest black
guard in creation. After this, we ask any man if
Mr. Harker is not guilty of every charge we have
made against him Of inconsistency, &c. in now ad-
vocating the cause of Gen. Jackson ? Who will
deny that he IS led by the nose by few men who, |
in 1922, thought no better of Gen. Jackson than
Mr.. Harker himself did, and who are now found in
the ranks of his supporters only because they flat
ter themselves that their own views will be promo
ted thereby Their golden prospects vanished like
dream when Mr.. Adams was elected, and their
oppositon to him is the effects of disappointed
ambition. The result of the next presidential
election may prove that they again wrong in
their calculations.


For the information of "Fair Play'' and the
public we would state that Albert Wilson, so tar
from being one of the most active individuals in
wilmington, in causing Book to be opened at
the Lafayette Iiotcl,' during the last Presidential
election, had nothing to do with procuring the Books

have thrown together few thoughts the subject o
EDucAroN, which have made Of in its broades
Education, by It's plastic and benign influence. produces
on the recipient creation; and enables the individual
upon whom it is advantageously employed, to deveope
his moral and physical eneges and thus to become
shining example his fellows, and active and useful
member of Society. Education, when it works properly
noble mind, ects to view those latent virtues and
energies, which, in the absence of it, would forever
main buried and lost both to the individual and to Society
Education is very apty and justly compared the culture
of the sell for, if DO not plough and SOW shall have
CROP BY the inyarabe laws of nature, it the spring
put forth blossoms in there will be beauty,
and in autumn fruit So, youth be aed away with
out improvement, manhood will be contemplate and old
age miserable and then vice will take possession of the
heart and bring forth uxurant crop Of the most baleful
propenstes and passions Education and virtue gene
rally coeva spring up spontaneously together and while
the enghcns, the other orti6es the heart Educa
ton is the fountain Of all those moral and social virtues
which alone adorn human nature, and render the
model of perfection 1t is education which swee
tens the temper and renders the recipient amabe and
aabe 1t expands the intellect, eevates the affections
and raises above all sublunay scenery; and we are
enabled to travel far the solar walk, or the milky
way, and, now and then, to sit among the stars.
